docs.snippet: The Times has been producing live video for Facebook with very mixed results. It’s time to find a better way.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Live: Too Much, Too Soon
headline.main: Facebook Live: Too Much, Too Soon

docs.snippet: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline.main: Donald Trump, Global Warming, Facebook: Your Wednesday Briefing

docs.snippet: To explore diversity in a time of violence, The New York Times commissioned an illustrator to create composite portraits from live Facebook comments.
The White House’s public Facebook page will allow people another avenue to advise, criticize or compliment President Obama.

headline.main: A New Way to Reach Obama: Facebook Messaging

docs.abstract: White House announces opening of Facebook messaging account, through which people can communicate with Pres Obama.

docs.snippet: The programs that prevent websites from displaying ads will be rendered useless for those accessing the social network’s desktop site, but not on mobile browsers.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Takes Steps to Defeat Ad Blockers
headline.main: Facebook Blocks Ad Blockers, but It Strives to Make Ads More Relevant

docs.abstract: Facebook installs software that renders ad blockers useless; change allows company to serve ads on its desktop site even to people who have ad-blocking software installed and running, move that is certain to inflame debate about ethics of ad blocking.

docs.snippet: If you do not want the world to see what you post on your timeline page, use the site’s settings to keep your thoughts out of public view.
docs.abstract: Tech Tip Q&A; explanation offered on how Facebook users can control who views particular post.

docs.snippet: Our reporters livestreamed their commutes on Facebook for a week. Here's what we found while commuting with you.

headline.main: Travel the World on Facebook Live

docs.snippet: Facebook is apologizing to advertisers for what it calls an error that overstated the average length of time users watched videos on the site.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Apologizes to Advertisers for Counting Error
headline.main: Facebook Apologizes to Advertisers for Counting Error

docs.snippet: A change in the social network’s algorithm is meant to identify misleading headlines on news stories and rank them lower, to keep users coming back.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Aims to Rid News Feed of ‘Clickbait’
headline.main: Shocker! Facebook Changes Its Algorithm to Avoid ‘Clickbait’

docs.abstract: Facebook says it is aiming to eliminate what it calls 'clickbait,' or misleading news stories by changing its news feed algorithm so that these stories are ranked lower; move is designed to keep its 1.71 billion users regularly coming back to social network.

docs.snippet: The country’s government is coming under criticism after the death of a journalist imprisoned under a new law that criminalizes offending the president.

headline.print_headline: Death of a Journalist Stirs Anger in Algeria
headline.main: Harsh Facebook Posts, Jail and Now Death: A Man’s Fate Angers Algeria

docs.abstract: Algerian government is receiving heavy criticism over death of freelance British-Algerian journalist Mohamed Tamalt, who died in prison while serving two-year sentence for insulting Pres Abdelaziz Bouteflika; Tamalt's death is embarrassment for authoritarian government, and his imprisonment sheds light on pressures embattled government is placing on independent news media.
